name: 2-cyano-4'-methylbiphenyl
Reason: The basic unit for the compound 2-cyano-4'-methylbiphenyl is biphenyl, which has a melting point of approximately 70°C. Adding a methyl group typically raises the melting point because it increases the molecular weight and provides additional van der Waals forces; this may add about +5°C. However, introducing a cyano group (-C≡N) into the compound tends to lower the melting point because it is a linear, electronegative group that can disrupt the regular packing of the molecules, resulting in weaker intermolecular forces in certain crystal lattices. The effect of a cyano group may subtract roughly -24°C. So, the net change would be (-24) + 5 = -19°C.
